title: Inflammatory Cytokine Responses to Progressive Resistance Training and Fortified Milk in Men Aged 50+ Years: An 18-Month Randomized Controlled Trial

sections.abstract:
We examined the effects of progressive resis-
tance training (PRT) and supplementation with calcium-
vitamin D 3 fortiﬁed milk on markers of systemic inﬂam-
mation, and the relationship between inﬂammation and
changes in muscle mass, size and strength. Healthy men
aged 50–79 years ( n = 180) participated in this 18-month
randomized controlled trial that comprised a factorial
2 9 2 design. Participants were randomized to (1)
PRT ? fortiﬁed milk supplement, (2) PRT, (3) fortiﬁed
milk supplement, or (4) a control group. Participants
assigned to PRT trained 3 days per week, while those in the
supplement groups consumed 400 ml day -1 of milk con-
taining 1,000 mg calcium plus 800 IU vitamin D 3.W e
collected venous blood samples at baseline, 12 and
18 months to measure the serum concentrations of IL-6,
TNF-a and hs-CRP. There were no exercise 9 supplement
interactions, but serum IL-6 was 29% lower (95% CI, -62,
0) in the PRT group compared with the control group after
12 months. Conversely, IL-6 was 31% higher (95% CI,
-2, 65) in the supplement group compared with the non-
supplemented groups after 12 and 18 months. These
between-group differences did not persist after adjusting
for changes in fat mass. In the PRT group, mid-tibia muscle
cross-sectional area increased less in men with higher pre-
training inﬂammation compared with those men with lower
inﬂammation (net difference * 2.5%, p \ 0.05). In con-
clusion, serum IL-6 concentration decreased following
PRT, whereas it increased after supplementation with for-
tiﬁed milk concomitant with changes in fat mass. Fur-
thermore, low-grade inﬂammation at baseline restricted
muscle hypertrophy following PRT.
Keywords Resistance training /C1 Calcium /C1 Vitamin D /C1 
Inﬂammation /C1 Elderly men
sections.introduction:
Aging is associated with chronic, low-grade inﬂammation
(Ferrucci et al. 2005; Penninx et al. 2004). The factors
contributing to this chronic inﬂammation in the elderly are
unclear, but likely involve age-related changes in immune
function, lifestyle and pathological conditions associated
with aging (Nicklas and Brinkley 2009). Cross-sectional
observations indicate an inverse relationship between
chronic inﬂammation and disability, muscle weakness and
atrophy in elderly people (Brinkley et al. 2009; Greiwe
et al. 2001; Leger et al. 2008; Penninx et al. 2004; Schaap
et al. 2009; Schaap et al. 2006; Tiainen et al. 2010). More
direct evidence from in vitro and in vivo studies also
Communicated by William J. Kraemer.
Electronic supplementary material The online version of this
article (doi:10.1007/s00421-011-1942-z) contains supplementary
material, which is available to authorized users.
J. M. Peake
The University of Queensland, School of Human Movement
Studies, Brisbane, Australia
J. M. Peake
The University of Queensland, Centre for Military and Veterans’
Health, Brisbane, Australia
S. Kukuljan /C1 C. A. Nowson /C1 R. M. Daly ( & )
Centre for Physical Activity and Nutrition Research,
School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences, Deakin University,
221 Burwood Highway, Melbourne, Burwood 3125, Australia
e-mail: robin.daly@deakin.edu.au
K. Sanders
Department of Clinical and Biomedical Sciences, Barwon
Health, The University of Melbourne, Geelong, Australia
123
Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088
DOI 10.1007/s00421-011-1942-z


indicates that inﬂammatory cytokines, such as IL-6 and
TNF-a, can inhibit muscle protein synthesis (for review see
Peake et al. 2010). Collectively, these ﬁndings support the
notion that chronic inﬂammation in elderly people can
contribute to loss of muscle mass and strength. This com-
bination of factors likely leads to a perpetual cycle of poor
functional capacity, low physical activity and persistent
inﬂammation among the elderly population.
Counteracting chronic, low-grade inﬂammation through
exercise training is potentially important for maintaining
muscle mass and strength, and reducing muscle loss in the
elderly (Bruunsgaard et al. 2004; Greiwe et al. 2001).
Exercise training—particularly aerobic endurance train-
ing—can reduce systemic and local inﬂammation (Donges
et al. 2010; Greiwe et al. 2001; Kohut et al. 2006; Lambert
et al. 2008; Nicklas et al. 2008; Phillips et al. 2010; Stewart
et al. 2005, 2007; Timmerman et al. 2008). Progressive
resistance training and aerobic training can also reduce
local and systemic inﬂammation in adults with chronic
disease (Castaneda et al. 2004; Gielen et al. 2003; Olson
et al. 2007). However, the long-term effects of progressive
resistance training on markers of inﬂammation and their
relationship to changes in muscle mass and muscular
strength in healthy middle-aged and older adults remain
uncertain.
Dietary interventions beyond caloric restriction alone
may also play an important role in reducing chronic low-
grade inﬂammation. Some evidence exists to suggest that
increased intake of dietary calcium promotes lipid metab-
olism and loss of body fat, and improves the inﬂammatory
risk proﬁle in overweight and obese subjects (Teegarden
et al. 2008; Zemel et al. 2005, 2010). Calcium appears
to inhibit lipogenesis and induces lipolysis by reducing
1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D-induced calcium signalling in
adipocytes (Shi et al. 2001). In contrast with the potential
obesogenic effects of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, vitamin D
deﬁciency is associated with poor musculoskeletal function
in the elderly (Dawson-Hughes 2008). Accordingly, vita-
min D supplementation, alone or in combination with
calcium, can improve muscle function (Dawson-Hughes
2008), and suppress the synthesis of CRP, TNF- a and IL-6
(Schleithoff et al. 2006; Van den Berghe et al. 2003).
The present study is a secondary analysis using archived
blood samples and existing data from an 18-month ran-
domized clinical trial on the effects of progressive resis-
tance training and calcium-vitamin D
3 fortiﬁed milk on
changes in bone and muscle mass, size and strength in
healthy middle-aged and elderly men. We have previously
reported data from this trial showing that progressive
resistance training signiﬁcantly improved leg muscle
strength by an average of 25%, total body lean mass by
0.6 kg, and mid-femur muscle cross-sectional area by
1.8%, and reduced fat mass by 1.1 kg (Kukuljan et al.
2009). In the present study, we have examined changes in
systemic markers of inﬂammation following this trial, and
investigated the relationship between inﬂammation and
changes in muscle mass, size and strength.
We conducted this secondary analysis for several rea-
sons. Firstly, relatively few controlled, longitudinal studies
have examined the relationship between inﬂammation and
changes in muscle mass, size and strength following more
than 3 months of resistance training (Bruunsgaard et al.
2004; Castaneda et al. 2004; Donges et al. 2010; Greiwe
et al. 2001). Secondly, not all studies investigating the
effects of resistance training on systemic inﬂammation
have evaluated changes in muscle strength and size or body
composition (Klimcakova et al. 2006; Kohut et al. 2006;
Phillips et al. 2010). Lastly, no studies have investigated
the combined effects of progressive resistance training and
supplementation with calcium-vitamin D
3 fortiﬁed milk on
systemic markers of inﬂammation. We hypothesized that
progressive resistance training and supplementation with
fortiﬁed milk would reduce systemic inﬂammation, and
this response would correlate with gains in muscle mass,
size and strength.
sections.methods:
Participants
As previously described (Kukuljan et al. 2008; Kukuljan
et al. 2009), healthy community dwelling Caucasian men
aged 50 -79 years were recruited from within the local
community in Geelong and surrounding areas in Victoria,
Australia. The exclusion criteria for this study were as
follows: (1) supplementation with calcium and/or vitamin
D in the past 12 months; (2) participation in progressive
resistance training in the past 12 months, and/or high-
impact weight-bearing activities for greater than 30 min
three times per week in the preceding 6 months; (3) body
mass index of [35 kg m
-2; (4) a history of osteoporotic
fracture or any medical condition or medication use known
to affect bone metabolism; (5) lactose intolerance; (6)
consumption of more than four standard alcoholic drinks
per day; (7) current smokers; and (8) any chronic condition
that might limit participation in the trial. Men with normal
to below average bone density (total hip or femoral neck
T score ?0.4 and -2.4 SD) were included in the study. All
eligible men were required to obtain medical clearance
from their local physician to ensure that they were free of
any contra-indicated medical conditions to exercise, based
on the American College of Sports Medicine guidelines
(American College of Sports Medicine 2000). The study
was approved by the Deakin University Human Ethics
Committee and Barwon Health Research and Ethics
3080 Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088
123


Advisory Committee, and written consent was obtained
from all participants.
Study design
Participants were randomly allocated to (1) exer-
cise ? supplement ( n = 45), (2) exercise alone ( n = 46),
(3) supplement alone ( n = 45), or (4) a control group
(n = 44). Prior to randomization, participants were strati-
ﬁed according to age ( \65 or C65 years) and dietary cal-
cium intake (\800 or C800 mg day
-1) assessed by a food
frequency questionnaire. Eight of the 180 men (4.4%)
withdrew from the study over the 18 months (exer-
cise ? supplement n = 2; exercise n = 2; supplement
n = 2; control n = 2). The reasons for withdrawal inclu-
ded: illness unrelated to the study ( n = 2); work or per-
sonal commitments (n = 5), and dissatisfaction with group
allocation (n = 1). Participants assigned to the usual care
control group were instructed to carry on with their normal
dietary habits and everyday activities of daily living. Using
this design, we were able to assess the independent and
combined effects of progressive resistance training and
supplementation with calcium-vitamin D
3 fortiﬁed milk on
serum cytokine and hs-CRP concentrations. This design
also allowed us to investigate the association between
changes in these systemic markers of inﬂammation and
body composition, muscle strength and muscle size. This
information is important because chronic, low-grade
inﬂammation can cause negative alterations in body com-
position, muscle strength and muscle size, leading to long-
term disease and disability in elderly populations.
Exercise training
Participants randomized to the exercise program were
asked to train on three non-consecutive days per week in
one of four community leisure facilities under the super-
vision of a qualiﬁed exercise trainer. Each exercise session
lasted 60–75 min, and consisted of warm-up and cool
down activities, and a series of progressive resistance
training and moderate impact weight-bearing exercises.
The 18-month periodized training program was divided
into six distinct 12 week mesocycles, each with three
4-week microcycles that were designed to be progressively
more challenging (Appendix 1). During the ﬁrst 4 weeks of
the program, all exercise sessions were supervised to
ensure correct lifting and landing technique and to monitor
the appropriate amount of exercise and rest intervals.
Thereafter, one session per week was supervised to provide
ongoing personal attention, tuition and supervision. For the
remaining two sessions, participants were instructed to
seek assistance from local trained gymnasium staff when
needed. Exercise compliance was computed from daily
exercise cards completed by the men at the gymnasium and
checked by records completed daily by the trainers that
were returned to the research staff every month. The
average adherence to the exercise program was 63% (95%
CI 57–69%), and did not differ between the exer-
cise ? supplement and exercise alone group (65 and 61%).
The progressive resistance training was of moderate- to
high-intensity, and included a combination of machine
and free weights and core muscle stabilization exercises
(Appendix 2). The key exercises used throughout the
program included: squats (or leg press), lunges, hip
abduction and adduction, latissimus dorsi pull down (or
seated row), back extension and a combination of
abdominal and core stability exercises. During the ﬁrst
12-week introductory mesocycle, participants completed
three sets of 15–20 repetitions at 50–60% of their one
repetition maximum (1-RM) strength. Thereafter, the
training volume was set at two sets of 8–12 repetitions at
60–85% of 1-RM. For the ﬁrst 12 months, all participants
were instructed to perform each repetition in a slow,
controlled manner, with a rest of 1–2 min between sets.
For the ﬁnal 6 months, the program switched to high
velocity, power-based training in which the participants
were instructed to perform all repetitions for each exer-
cise as rapidly as possible during the lifting phase, and
then return the weight to the start position in a slow and
controlled speed. Interspersed between the resistance
exercises were three lower extremity weight-bearing
impact exercises. Participants were required to complete
three sets of 10–20 repetitions for each impact exercise
(Appendix 2). The total number of ﬂoor contacts
(impacts) per session therefore ranged from 90 to 180.
The magnitude, rate and direction of these impact loads
were also progressively increased throughout the program
by either increasing the height of jumps and/or by intro-
ducing more complex movement patterns.
Calcium-vitamin D
3 supplement
Participants assigned to the supplement protocol were
asked to consume 2 9 200 ml tetra packs of reduced fat
(* 1%) ultra high temperature (UHT) milk per day, spe-
ciﬁcally formulated by Murray Goulburn Co-operative Co.
Ltd (Brunswick, Australia). All men were asked to main-
tain their usual dietary habits and were not restricted from
eating other dairy products (e.g., cheese, yoghurt) during
the course of the study. Each 200 ml milk tetra pack
contained * 500 mg of calcium and 400 IU of vitamin D
3,
418 kJ energy, 6.6 g protein, 2.2 g fat, 11 g lactose,
100 mg sodium and 250 mg phosphorous. The milk was
fortiﬁed with a calcium salt derived from fresh milk whey.
The vitamin D (vitamin D
3) that was used to fortify the
milk was obtained from DSM Nutritional Products Pty Ltd
Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088 3081
123

(NSW, Australia). Six batches of the milk were produced
over the 18-month intervention, and participants received a
new batch every 3 months. The average ( ±SD) amount of
calcium was 247 ± 17 mg, and the average amount of
vitamin D 3 was 190 ± 26 IU per 100 ml for the six bat-
ches. Participants recorded the number of tetra packs
consumed per day on compliance calendars, which were
collected and checked every 3 months. The average com-
pliance with the supplement was 90% (95% CI 87–93%),
and was not different between the exercise ? supplement
and supplement group (92 and 89%).
Inﬂammatory markers
Fasting, morning (8–10 am) blood samples (10 ml) were
obtained from an antecubital vein at baseline, 12 and
18 months. Blood was left to clot at room temperature
before serum was aliquoted and stored at -80/C176 C until the
day of analysis. Serum concentrations of IL-6 and TNF- a
were measured using Quantikine
/C210 High-Sensitivity
Cytokine ELISA kits (R&D Systems, Minneapolis, MN,
USA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Absorbance was read on a microplate reader (FLUOstar
Optima, BMG Labtech, Offenburg, Germany). hs-CRP
was measured using a high-sensitivity turbidimetric assay
(Kamiya Biomedical Co., Seattle, WA, USA) conducted
on an automated analyser (Cobas MIRA, Roche Diag-
nostics, Basel, Switzerland). Because of the large number
of samples ([500), we performed single assays. The intra-
assay CV for IL-6 and TNF- a was consistently \6%, and
the intra-assay CV for hs-CRP was \2%. To reduce inter-
assay variation, samples from each participant in each
group were analysed on the same ELISA microplate on
the same day, while hs-CRP was measured in all samples
on 1 day.
Anthropometry, diet, physical activity, and medication
use
Body height was assessed using a Holtain wall stadiometer
(Crymych, Dyfed, UK) and body mass was measured using
an A&D UC-321 electronic scale to the nearest 0.1 kg.
Nutrient intakes were assessed using a 3-day food diary
(2 weekdays and one weekend day) at baseline, 12 and
18 months, and analysed using the Foodworks nutrient
analysis software program (Xyris Software, Brisbane,
Queensland, Australia). Leisure time and habitual physical
activity outside of the exercise intervention (kJ week
-1)
were also assessed at each time point using the CHAMPS
Physical Activity Questionnaire (Stewart et al. 2001). A
questionnaire and/or interview was used at each visit to
obtain information about disease history and the use of any
medication.
Muscle strength, muscle mass and size
The methodology related to the assessment of muscle
strength, muscle mass and size has been reported in detail
previously (Kukuljan et al. 2008; Kukuljan et al. 2009).
Brieﬂy, muscle strength (one repetition maximum, 1-RM)
was assessed every 3 months in the exercise groups and at
baseline, 12 and 18 months in the non-exercise groups. Leg
press, latissimus dorsi pull down, and bench press exercises
were used to document changes in upper and lower body
muscle strength. Total body lean mass (LM) and fat mass
(FM) were assessed at baseline, 12 and 18 months using
DXA (Prodigy, GE Lunar Corp., Madison, WI, USA). Mid-
femur and mid-tibia muscle cross-sectional area (CSA) was
assessed using quantitative computed tomography (QCT)
[Philips Mx8000 CT scanner (Philips Mx8000 Quad CT
scanner, Philips Medical Systems, The Netherlands).
Statistical analysis
Statistical analyses were conducted using Stata Statistical
Software release 8.0 (Stata, College Station, TX, USA).
Baseline characteristics between the groups were compared
using ANOVA for continuous variables and Chi-squared
tests for categorical variables. Pooled time series regression
analysis for longitudinal data was used to test for an
interaction between exercise and calcium-vitamin D
3.T h i s
analysis is similar to an intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis, in
that it includes all participants who entered the study and
had at least one follow-up measurement. If no signiﬁcant
interactions were detected, the main effects of exercise
(exercise ? supplement and exercise alone vs. supplement
and control) and calcium-vitamin D
3 supplementation
(exercise ? supplement and supplement versus exercise
and controls) were examined. All inﬂammatory markers
were log transformed prior to analysis and adjusted for
change in total body fat mass. Separate models were used
to assess the within-group changes, which were expressed
either as absolute changes or as percentage changes from
baseline. Percentage changes in the log transformed
inﬂammatory markers represent the absolute differences
from baseline multiplied by 100. Linear regression analysis
was used to investigate whether baseline inﬂammatory
markers were associated with the change in total body lean
mass, muscle CSA and strength, independent of changes in
fat mass. Because increased levels of two or more inﬂam-
matory markers are likely to provide a more speciﬁc indi-
cator of low-grade systemic inﬂammation than just a high
level of one inﬂammatory marker (Cauley et al. 2007), we
developed a composite inﬂammatory index for participants
in the exercise and exercise ? supplement groups, based on
the number of markers in the highest tertile. Those with two
or more inﬂammatory markers in the highest tertile were
3082 Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088
123


classiﬁed as having a ‘high’ level of inﬂammation, those
with only one marker in the highest tertile were classiﬁed as
having a ‘mid’ level of inﬂammation, and those with no
marker in the highest tertile were classiﬁed as having a ‘low’
level of inﬂammation. All data are presented as means ± SD
or 95% CI, unless stated otherwise.
sections.results:
Baseline characteristics
At baseline, there were no between group differences for
any of the characteristics, with the exception that alcohol
intake was greater in the control compared with the sup-
plement group (p \ 0.05) (Tables 1 and 2). In addition, the
prevalence of cardiovascular disease was higher in the men
allocated to the exercise and control groups. As reported
previously (Kukuljan et al. 2009), daily nutrient intakes
were also similar between the groups, but back and leg
muscle strength were greater in the control group compared
with the exercise and exercise ? supplement group at
baseline (both p \0.05).
Effects of exercise and calcium-vitamin D
3
on inﬂammatory markers
There were no signiﬁcant exercise 9 supplement interac-
tions for any of the inﬂammatory markers; accordingly, we
report the main effects for exercise and supplementation
(Table 2). After 12 months, log-transformed serum IL-6
concentrations tended to be lower in the exercise compared
with the non-exercise group [mean net percentage differ-
ence for the change (95% CI) -29% ( -62 to 0%),
p = 0.06]. This trend did not persist, however, after
adjusting for changes in FM ( p = 0.14). Main effects
analysis of the supplement revealed that serum IL-6 con-
centration tended to increase in the supplement compared
with non-supplemented groups after 12 months (32%,
p = 0.05), which persisted after 18 months (31%,
p = 0.06) (Table 2). However, these between-group dif-
ferences did not persist after adjusting for changes in FM
(p [ 0.10). Serum TNF- a and hs-CRP concentrations did
not change signiﬁcantly in any group and exercise com-
pliance was not correlated with the 12 or 18 months
changes in any of the inﬂammatory markers ( r range -0.15
to 0.01). In addition, adjusting for the use of medications
(NSAIDS, lipid-lowering, anti-hypertensive and diabetic)
in the statistical analysis did not alter any of the results.
Relationship between inﬂammation
and exercise-induced changes in muscle
A secondary aim of the study was to investigate whether
inﬂammatory markers were associated with exercise-
induced changes in muscle. We have previously reported
that total body lean increased by 0.6 kg ( p \0.05) and
total body fat mass decreased by 1.1 kg ( p \ 0.001) after
18 months in the exercise compared with the non-exercise
group (Kukuljan et al. 2009). There was also a net 1.8%

exercise-induced gain in mid-femur muscle CSA
(p \ 0.001), but no overall effects of exercise on mid-tibia
muscle CSA. Exercise also signiﬁcantly increased both
upper and lower body muscle strength (mean increase 23%
for all exercises) after 18 months, ( p \ 0.001) (Kukuljan
et al. 2009). Baseline concentrations of each of the log
transformed inﬂammatory markers were not related to the
exercise-induced changes in muscle strength, total body
LM or muscle CSA at either site (Table 3). When the
inﬂammatory markers were combined to form a composite
index at baseline, exercise-induced gains in LM and muscle
strength were similar between the three tertiles of inﬂam-
mation (Fig. 1). In contrast, changes in muscle CSA at the
mid-tibia were signiﬁcantly smaller in men categorized as
having ‘high’ versus ‘low’ inﬂammatory markers at base-
line ( p \ 0.05), even after adjusting for changes in FM
(Fig. 1). A similar trend was observed at the mid-femur,
but the 1.7% difference between the ‘high’ and the ‘low’
and ‘mid’ inﬂammatory marker groups was not signiﬁcant
(p = 0.27). In the non-exercise group, muscle mass, CSA
and strength did not differ among the three inﬂammatory
categories (data not presented).
sections.discussion:
This study investigated whether progressive resistance
training and supplementation with calcium-vitamin D for-
tiﬁed milk would reduce systemic inﬂammation, and
whether this response would be associated with gains in
muscle mass, size and strength. Resistance training reduced
fat mass and IL-6, whereas supplementation with fortiﬁed
milk increased fat mass and tended to increase IL-6. We
also observed that muscle hypertrophy was greatest fol-
lowing resistance training in men with a low degree of
systemic inﬂammation at the beginning of the trial. These
ﬁndings highlight the beneﬁts of resistance training for
reducing fat mass and inﬂammation in middle-aged and
older men, and also suggest that consuming milk fortiﬁed
with calcium and vitamin D
3 may negate these beneﬁts
because of the concomitant gains in fat mass.
Studies on the effects of resistance training as a single
intervention on inﬂammatory cytokines or their soluble
receptors in healthy, elderly people have produced equiv-
ocal ﬁndings (Beavers et al. 2010; Bruunsgaard et al. 2004;
Donges et al. 2010; Greiwe et al. 2001; Klimcakova et al.

2006; Stewart et al. 2007). In the present study, we
observed that serum IL-6 concentrations tended to
decrease after 12 months of resistance training, but this
effect did not persist after accounting for the exercise-
related effects on fat mass. This ﬁnding suggests that
changes in serum IL-6 concentrations mainly depend on
changes in fat mass. This ﬁnding contrasts with cross-
sectional observations that regular physical activity is
inversely correlated with CRP, irrespective of BMI
(Abramson and Vaccarino 2002; Church et al. 2002).
Nicklas et al. ( 2004) have reported that diet-induced
weight loss, but not exercise training, signiﬁcantly reduced
the concentrations of a number of inﬂammatory markers
(e.g., CRP, IL-6, soluble TNF- a receptor 1). However, the
changes in CRP and IL-6 in the weight loss group were not
related to the amount of body mass lost or baseline BMI
(Nicklas et al. 2004). Other research indicates that changes
in inﬂammation following exercise training depend on
alterations in central fat distribution, rather than loss of
body mass (Dekker et al. 2007). Collectively, these ﬁnd-
ings suggest that systemic inﬂammation in elderly people
may be related to other underlying physiological mecha-
nisms associated with weight loss (or energy restriction),
as opposed to changes in body fat per se.
The effectiveness of exercise training for reducing
inﬂammation appears to vary depending on the major body
tissues that are metabolically active during exercise,
or alternatively, the source of inﬂammation. Resistance
training reduces local inﬂammation within skeletal muscle
(Gielen et al. 2003; Greiwe et al. 2001; Lambert et al.
2008), but is less effective for reducing systemic inﬂam-
mation (Bruunsgaard et al. 2004; Kohut et al. 2006).
Resistance exercise down-regulates proteolytic signaling
pathways linked with inﬂammation in skeletal muscle
(Louis et al. 2007), but does not reduce inﬂammation in
adipose tissue (Klimcakova et al. 2006). Aerobic training
may be more effective than resistance training for reducing
systemic inﬂammation (Kohut et al. 2006; Nicklas et al.
2008), because aerobic training reduces inﬂammation in
adipose tissue (Bruun et al. 2006). Several intervention
studies involving elderly people have reported no changes
in serum inﬂammatory markers following 3–8 months of
resistance training (Bruunsgaard et al. 2004; Kapasi et al.
2003; Klimcakova et al. 2006).
The relatively low-grade inﬂammatory state of the
middle-aged and elderly men enrolled in our study could
possibly explain the modest changes in systemic inﬂam-
mation following resistance training. We speciﬁcally

cross-sectional area (CSA) and
total body lean mass and muscle
strength (average upper and
lower body) in the exercise and
exercise ? supplement groups
according to the baseline

inﬂammatory markers in the

Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088 3085
123


recruited healthy, community-dwelling middle-aged and
elderly men who were screened by their physician for any
contraindications to exercise prior to commencing the
training. Most previous studies that have reported a bene-
ﬁcial effect of resistance training on markers of inﬂam-
mation have included adults with a chronic disease (e.g.,
heart failure, kidney disease, obesity, diabetes) (Castaneda
et al. 2004; Gielen et al. 2003; Olson et al. 2007). The men
in our study were, on average, overweight based on their
BMI (mean 27.5 kg m
-2), whereas their average baseline
serum hs-CRP concentration was 1.27 mg L -1. Concen-
trations of hs-CRP in the range of 1–3 mg L -1 are asso-
ciated with a moderate risk for cardiovascular disease,
whereas a value greater than 3 mg L -1 is linked with a
high risk (Pearson et al. 2003).
We found no correlation between any of the inﬂam-
matory markers, and changes in total body lean mass,
regional muscle CSA or strength following progressive
resistance training. However, using a composite inﬂam-
matory marker index, we found that mid-tibia muscle CSA
increased over 18 months in the exercise group with a
lower level of inﬂammation at baseline. This ﬁnding is
consistent with observations in cross-sectional studies that
a high level of inﬂammation is associated with lower
muscle mass and strength in elderly men and women
(Brinkley et al. 2009; Schaap et al. 2009). Data from other
studies also indicate an inverse relationship between indi-
vidual inﬂammatory markers and changes in muscle
strength, size and protein synthesis following 3 months of
resistance training (Bruunsgaard et al. 2004; Castaneda
et al. 2004; Greiwe et al. 2001). Although our ﬁndings are
not new, they provide evidence that chronic low-grade
inﬂammation restricts gains in muscle size over a period of
more than 3 months.
Some evidence suggest that dietary calcium and/or
vitamin D may modulate adipocyte cytokine production,
possibly by reducing obesity. Increased intake of dairy
products reduces plasma cytokine concentrations, and
increases plasma adiponectin concentration in obese indi-
viduals (Zemel et al. 2010). These improvements in the
inﬂammatory risk proﬁle of obese individuals may be
related to increased loss of fat mass and fat oxidation and
total body fat (Teegarden et al. 2008; Zemel et al. 2005). In
a randomized controlled trial of 123 heart failure patients
who received 50 lg day
-1 vitamin D3 and 500 mg day -1
calcium or placebo for 9 months, serum TNF- a concen-
tration remained stable in the supplemented group, but
increased in the placebo group (Schleithoff et al. 2006).
Conversely, the anti-inﬂammatory cytokine IL-10 increased
in the supplement group compared with the placebo group
(Schleithoff et al. 2006). In healthy postmenopausal
women, Grey et al. (Grey et al. 2006) found that supple-
mentation with 1,000 mg of calcium daily for 12 months
did not alter CRP levels. Contrary to the above ﬁndings, we
found that 18 months supplementation with 1,000 mg
calcium and 800 IU vitamin D 3 per day tended to increase
serum IL-6 concentration in middle-aged and elderly men.
This increase in serum IL-6 concentration was largely due
to the small, but signiﬁcant mean increase (0.6–0.7 kg) in
fat mass in the supplement group.
The variation between our ﬁndings and those of other
studies with respect to the anti-inﬂammatory effects of
calcium and vitamin D
3 may be related to several factors.
First, calcium and vitamin D 3 may be more effective for
reducing inﬂammation in elderly women, obese individu-
als, or those with other chronic diseases. Second, the
greater energy content of milk may promote gains in fat
mass, thereby mitigating the potential beneﬁts of the cal-
cium and vitamin D
3. It is possible that these nutrients
may be more effective for reducing inﬂammation when
consumed as tablets. Participants were not restricted
from eating other dairy products (e.g., cheese, yoghurt)
during the course of the study. Daily intakes of energy,
macronutrients, calcium and vitamin D were not signiﬁ-
cantly different between groups at baseline (Kukuljan et al.
2009). Although vitamin D intake increased signiﬁcantly in
the non-supplement groups during the ﬁrst 12 months of the
study, this increase (* 1.5-fold) was substantially smaller than
the 14-fold increase in vitamin D intake in the supplement
groups (Kukuljan et al. 2009). Therefore, changes in back-
ground dietary intake most likely did not inﬂuence changes in
inﬂammation, muscle mass, size and strength.
The strengths of this study include the factorial design,
the large sample size, the long period of investigation, and
the compliance of participants in consuming the milk
supplement. There were also several limitations. First, we
studied a cohort of ambulatory, community-dwelling
middle-aged and elderly men with adequate baseline cal-
cium intake and sufﬁcient circulating serum 25-OHD
3
concentrations. Second, measuring changes in systemic
inﬂammation may not accurately reﬂect the beneﬁts of
resistance training in older adults compared with assessing
local inﬂammation within skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.
Last, we did not assess circulating concentrations of IL-6 or
TNF-a soluble receptors, which may be more representa-
tive of the inﬂammatory response, because of the short
half-life of IL-6 and TNF- a (Nicklas et al. 2004).
In
sections.conclusion:
, the ﬁndings from this long-term, ran-
domized controlled trial indicate that combining resistance
training with calcium-vitamin D fortiﬁed milk did not
inﬂuence systemic inﬂammation in healthy middle-aged
and elderly men. Rather, the effects of resistance training
and supplementation with calcium-vitamin D fortiﬁed milk
appeared to be independent. Serum IL-6 concentration
tended to decrease after resistance training, whereas
it tended to increase following supplementation with
3086 Eur J Appl Physiol (2011) 111:3079–3088
123


calcium-vitamin D fortiﬁed milk. These alterations were
dependent on changes in fat mass. Higher pre-training
levels of inﬂammation were associated with a reduced
skeletal muscle response to the training, which adds sup-
port to the notion that low-grade inﬂammation may atten-
uate exercise-induced gains in muscle size in elderly
people. Since resistance training in elderly people can
maintain muscle mass, while aerobic exercise can stimulate
fat metabolism and reduce inﬂammation in adipose tissue,
future studies should focus on examining the combined
effects of resistance and aerobic training, with or without
dietary intervention, on markers of both local and systemic
inﬂammation.
